description: The government ordered the army on Friday to resolve a violent land dispute in a remote northern forest reserve, where 17 people have been killed.
title: Paraguay: Army to Intervene in Dispute Over Land
title_page: Paraguay: Army to Intervene in Dispute Over Land - The New York Times
maintext: The government ordered the army on Friday to resolve a violent land dispute in a remote northern forest reserve, where 17 people have been killed in gun battles between the police and landless farmers. The police were trying to evict about 150 farmers from the reserve, which is part of a huge estate owned by Blas Riquelme, a politician opposed to President Fernando Lugo. Seven police officers and 10 farmers have been killed in the forest, about 150 miles north of the capital, Asunci√≥n. Advocates for poor farmers say the land, acquired from the state decades ago by Mr. Riquelme, should have been part of a land reform program. Mr. Lugo won an election in 2008 in part on a promise of agrarian reform that would benefit 87,000 Paraguayan farm families, though as he nears the end of his term he has yet to deliver.
